title: ABOUT THE COURSE
body: The course critically highlights current educational issues and policies across countries published in various reputable sources, such as scientific journals, proceedings, magazines, films, videos, and newspapers. Discussion, report writing, presentation, and debates are conducted on the bases of the priority issues currently in the attention of various academic forums.

title: Hello!
body:
For those who got the chance to discuss the topic on Literacy Enrichment Across Countries on the last assignment, now it is your turn to share your findings here.

Post your result of discussion in ppt format and let your friends ask you some questions about the topic.

This forum of discussion is belongs to you!

Be an active student, we will monitor you on this forum.

Regards,

IM & TP

_items.title: Attendance
_items.body: Attendance to 80% of the overall number of class meetings (synchronous and asynchronous learning) in the semester is a prerequisite to take the final test and/or to get the final mark. Attendance is not counted as part of the final mark.

_items.title: Latecomers
_items.body: An attendance to a class meeting of synchronous learning is taken 10 minutes after the class starts. More-than-10-minute latecomers are allowed to attend the class but the attendance is not counted.

_items.title: Missed Exams/Assignments
_items.body: Each will score and will be equally counted as part of the average score for the final mark.

_items.title: Academic Dishonesty
_items.body:
• It is considered a serious crime and seriously taken as an offence to the students’ academic integrity. Therefore, any evidence of plagiarism of any amount will result in a Failed mark.

  • Students are to obey standard policy and regulations on honesty in academic work and avoid committing plagiarism and cheating in any assigned work.

  • Committing plagiarism in an academic work and/or cheating on an exam  will result in a “0” for the work and/or exam.

  • Details on plagiarism may be found at http://www.plagiarism.org.

_items.title: Attitude In The Classroom
_items.body:
Students have to participate actively in the class activities by:

  1. presenting their best ideas and thoughts coherently,
  2. using their best English in regard to the pronunciation, word stressing, and intonation, and
  3. demonstrating socially acceptable manner.

_items.title: Working from home and/or in the library
Keeping 4 Cs (Communication, Critical thinking, Creativity, and Collaboration)

title: REFERENCES
body:
• Bulman, Jenny H. (2017). Children's Reading of Film and Visual Literacy in the Primary Curriculum. A Progression Framework Model. Lincolnshire, UK: Springer International Publishing.
  • Christensen, Clayton dan Eyring, Henry, J. (2012). The innovative university: changing the DNA of higher education. Forum for the Future of Higher Education. 47-57
  • Dyer, Jeff, Gregerson, Hal, Christensen, Clayton.M. (2011). The innovators’s DNA: mastering the five skills of disruptive innovators. Boston, Mass: Harvard Business Review Press.
  • Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan. 2020. "Merdeka Belajar. Episode Kelima. Guru Penggerak" Jakarta: Kemendikbud.
  • Mayuni, Ilza et.al. (2020). School Literacy Movement and Its Implications towards students: A Comparative Case Study in Jakarta and Taiwan. International Journal of Advanced Science and Technology. Vol.29. 2020.
  • UNESCO. 2016. Metacognition “How we reflect, learn, and adapt”. Paris: UNESCO.
  • OECD. 2011. Building a high quality teaching profession: lessons from around the world.
  • Gibs, Paul. 2017. Transdisciplinary Higher Education: A Theoretical Basis Revealed in Practice. London: Middlesex University.
  • Lombardi, Marilyn M. (2007). Authentic Learning for the 21st-Century: an overview.  Educause, Learning Initiative.
  • Saavedra, Anna R. Dan Opfer, V.D. (2012). Teaching and learning 21st-century skills: lessons from the learning sciences. RAND Corporation.
  • UNESCO 2020. Inclusion and Education. All Means All. Paris: UNESCO.

title: STUDIES ON 21st CENTURY SKILLS
body:
World Economic Forum 2016. Future of Work Report, 2016.
Deloitte Global Human Capital Report, 2017. Gallup State of the American Workplace 2017.

_items.body: 33% of core skills for most jobs by 2020 will include skills that aren’t considered important today.
77% of companies will either retrain people to use technology or redesign jobs to better leverage “people” skills.
94% of companies say agility and collaboration are critical to their success, yet only 6% consider themselves “highly agile” today.
84% of employees work in networked/ matrixed environments , requiring stronger relationship and self management skills.

title: Text Video
body: In this video, 21st century life skills are divided into two components, the first being student outcomes, and the second being support systems for teachers.

_items.title: Student outcomes are broken down into four different categories.
_items.body:
The first category is Key subjects and 21st century themes that cross between disciplines within school curriculum.

The second part of student outcomes is information, media, and technology along with digital citizenship and student online safety.

The next category is learning environments, learning skills, and innovation skills.

And the last section of student outcomes is life and career skills. Career skills are something that educators need to focus on in their classroom.

_items.title: The Educator and Student Support Systems
_items.body: The second component of this is the educator and student support systems. The student support systems is dividing into five parts, the first being 21st century standards, the second being assessments for these life skills and career skills, the next one is curriculum and assessments, which is then followed by professional development, and lastly learning environments.

title: Learning to live together in peace through Global Citizenship Education
Text Video
body:
Watch the video. This video is from the UNESCO on “Learning to live together in peace through Global Citizenship Education” which explains the importance of Global Citizenship Education (GCED) in a globalized and increasingly interconnected and interdependent world. GCED is key to understand the interconnections between the local and the global and nurture a sense of belonging to a common humanity. It builds motivation to assume active roles to contribute to a more just, peaceful, tolerant and sustainable world. The video also illustrates how GCED can be delivered in and outside of schools.

Answer the following questions.

_items.body: What is global citizenship and why is it important?
How would you promote global citizenship in your classroom?

title: DATA LITERACY
body: Data Literacy is ability to:

_items.body: read, analyze, work with, and argue with data;
communicate, write, and read about data in context;

title: LITERACY AND LEARNING
body: Language is the predominant form of literacy that shapes the way you think and determines what you can think about. Literacy is a life skill that empowers individuals to learn independently. Improving literacy and learning can have an impact on students’ self-esteem, motivation and behaviour.

_items.body: Indonesian adult with tertiary education has lower literacy proficiency than typical Greek or Dane with lower secondary literacy and other OECD country with upper secondary schooling. (OECD PIAAC, 2016)
Many Indonesians are taught  to think together and repeat the consensus rather than think individually and critically.

title: THINKING SKILLS
body:
• as a representational system in human thinking
  • result in different degrees of success
  • involves emotions

_items.title: Apply
_items.body:
How is it used?

How does it work?

_items.title: Analyze
_items.body:
What is the cause?

What is the reason?

Why is it used?

Why does it work?

What does it infer?

What does it suggest?

_items.title: Evaluate
_items.body:
What is the effect?

What is the impact?

What is the result?

What if?

What would happen?

What could happen?

_items.title: Create
_items.body:
What can you design?

How would you develop?

What can you plan?

What could you produce?

How can you innovate?

What can you invert?

title: TEACHER'S CHALLENGES
body: Preparing students to become literate and independent learners who are able to:

_items.title: pursue information related to personal interests
appreciate literature and other creative expressions

back.body: 21st Century skills empower students to learn independently.
Literacy is best taught as part of the subject.
Good literacy skills are a key factor in raising standards across all subjects.
Improving literacy and learning can have an impact on pupils’ self-esteem, motivation and behaviour.
Literacy development should start  from early childhood care and quality basic education for all children.
School and parents need to scale-up functional literacy levels for youth and adults who lack basic literacy skills.
Literate environments should be developed from home, schools, and communities.

body: Watch the video on The OECD Teaching and Learning International Survey (TALIS) which asked teachers and school leaders from 48 countries and economies about their views on innovative teaching practices for the modern world.

title: Text
body:
Answer the following questions:

  1. Who do you think are the intended audiences?
  2. What is the video about? Does it make sense?
  3. What are the main messages? Do you agree/disagree? Why?
  4. How does the video make you feel?
  5. What have you learnt as a result of watching the video?

_items.body: Use a newly learned skill in various contexts.

Emphasize the building blocks of higher-order thinking by:

  • building background knowledge,
  • classifying things in categories,
  • arranging items along dimensions,
  • making hypotheses,
  • drawing inferences,
  • analyzing things into their components, and
  • solving problems.
Develop your capacity through speaking and listening, visualizing and observing, and reading and writing.
Learn to analyze, evaluate, and produce texts across various modes of language.
Develop multiple literacies  through teamwork and problem solving activities.

title: International Literacy Day 2020 – Teaching and learning literacy in the COVID-19 crisis and beyond
body: Before we focus on Indonesian Literacy Rate, let's have a look on the International Literacy Day 2020 which focus on Literacy teaching and learning in the COVID-19 crisis and beyond with a focus on the role of educators and changing pedagogic. Since 1967, International Literacy Day (ILD) celebrations have occurred every year around the globe to help people in general to remember the significance of education as an issue of nobility and basic freedoms, and to propel the literacy plan towards a more proficient and literate society.

title: Text
body: You may take notes on some important points.

title: Text
body:
Read the journal article published by International Journal of Advanced Science and Technology Vol. 29, No. 4s, (2020), pp. 1555-1569 by Prof. Dr. Ilza Mayuni et.al.

School Literacy Movement and Its Implications towards Students Learning: A Comparative Case Study in Jakarta and Taiwan.

 

Take notes and highlight on some important point.

Submit your work and you will receive feedback after your submission.

_items.title: Challenges we face in preparing prospective English teachers
Proposed strategies to meet the needs of students in the job market

title: Challenges: ICT Development Index
body: International Telecommunication Union (2018)

_captions.text: Teacher stands in front of the class.
Internet may take over most of teacher’s responsibility.
Student has self-determination  to learn what, how, where, and when they want to learn.

title: Trends in Education of 4IR
body: (Gibson, Ostashewski, Flintoff, Grant, & Knight, 2015; Fisk, 2017)

_items.title: Learning will be personalized to individual students.
Learning can be taken place anytime and anywhere.
Students are exposed to data interpretation and allowed to use their reasoning skills.
Students’ opinion will be considered in designing and updating the curriculum.
Students will be exposed to more project-based learning.
Students will be assessed differently (no more conventional platforms).
Students pursue different  routes to achieve the same skills.

title: Micro-Credentials?
body: It is a competency-based digital form of certification to recognize student’s skills, achievements and accomplishments of a specific skill and/or sub-skills. This can be obtained from formal and/or informal learning experiences.

title: Micro-Credentials?
body: Micro-credentials can be issued by internal and/or external institutions to improve professional practice that supports student’s success when they enter workplace when they graduate.

title: Policy and Strategies for New Direction
displayTitle: Policy and Strategies for New Direction

back.body: First, there should be a clear map of (sub) competences/skills the prospective teachers need to master for a teaching position.
Then clear criteria and mechanism for submitting  evidence, scaling, receiving digital badges, and any other mechanism.
There should be a committee who work not only to approve but also continuously update the development in the workplace so that they can give feedback for quality improvement of the SKPI policy.
Another most important strategy is to establish an alignment with institutions for recognition.

_items.title: 4IR brings significant impacts  on English teacher profession. Preparing English teachers can no longer be seen as business as usual type of duty.
Exigence for ELE-SP to produce significant changes in terms of institutional mindset, curriculum, and  infrastructures to provide students with high level of competencies needed for 4IR contexts.
Besides language and teaching skills, an effective micro-credential system may be worth to plan as an integral part of the curriculum for more competitive graduates.
“It is not only changing what we do  but also what we are.”
Jobs nowadays require not only academic qualification but  more specific skills as well as good characters.
What happens in our classroom, little has changed particularly in the way teacher institution & employers assess and value education.

Therefore, it is a must for ELE-SP to shift paradigm in teaching-learning to prepare future teachers. If we still teach the way they were taught years ago, I am afraid teachers are no longer needed and replaced by virtual classroom, virtual reality and virtual teachers.
